parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Evidence regarding the impact of substituting fish meal with bacterial protein on Atlantic salmon is varied.
[Statement 2]: Two controlled studies in Norway indicated that salmon fed diets with up to 25% bacterial protein had similar growth rates to salmon on a 100% fish meal diet.
[Statement 3]: In two controlled studies in Norway, salmon growth rates were lower with a 50% bacterial protein diet.
[Statement 4]: Another Norwegian study found that diets with 18% and 36% bacterial protein resulted in higher growth rates in Atlantic salmon compared to a control group.
[Statement 5]: Six studies in Norway, Scotland, and the USA reported decreased growth rates in salmon fed plant-based proteins.
[Statement 6]: Three studies in Norway, Canada, and Scotland found that salmon fed plant-based proteins had similar growth rates to salmon on fish meal diets.
[Statement 7]: Four controlled studies in Norway and Scotland noted reduced final body weights in salmon on plant-based diets.
[Statement 8]: Two controlled studies in Norway found that salmon on plant-based diets had similar final body weights to salmon on fish meal diets.
[Statement 9]: Two controlled studies in Norway observed lower feeding efficiency in salmon with plant-based diets.
[Statement 10]: One replicated study in Norway reported an increase in feeding efficiency with plant-based diets.
[Statement 11]: The digestibility of feed was found to be lower in two studies with plant protein diets.
[Statement 12]: Two other studies in Scotland and Norway reported that plant protein diets had similar levels of digestibility to fish meal diets.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__How do plant-based and bacterial protein alternatives to fish meal compare in terms of their effect on Atlantic salmon growth rates in Norway?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Two controlled studies in Iceland and Norway investigating disease-causing bacteria reported higher survival rates in vaccinated salmon compared to unvaccinated salmon.
[Statement 2]: Two controlled studies in Australia and Canada found that vaccinated salmon infected with marine flexibacteriosis and bacterial kidney disease had higher survival rates.
[Statement 3]: For salmon vaccinated against infectious salmon anaemia, two controlled studies in Norway reported higher survival rates.
[Statement 4]: A replicated, controlled study in Norway observed increased survival levels in salmon from families bred for high resistance to infectious pancreatic necrosis compared to salmon from families bred for low resistance.
[Statement 5]: A study in Australia found no difference in mortality from Amoebic Gill Disease in cages where a fallowing system had been used.
[Statement 6]: A study in Scotland recorded lower lice numbers on Atlantic salmon in cages that used a fallowing system.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__Which interventions appear most effective for increasing the survival rates of farmed salmon exposed to disease?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Studies in Norway and Scotland have documented the effects of including plant-based proteins in salmon feed.
[Statement 2]: The inclusion of plant-based proteins in salmon feed led to decreased growth rates in salmon.
[Statement 3]: Some studies found similar growth rates between salmon fed plant-based diets and salmon fed fish meal diets.
[Statement 4]: Salmon on plant-based protein diets had reduced final body weights compared to salmon on fish meal-based diets.
[Statement 5]: Some studies found no difference in final body weights between salmon fed plant-based protein diets and salmon fed fish meal-based diets.
[Statement 6]: Feeding efficiency was reported to be lower in salmon fed plant-based protein diets.
[Statement 7]: An increase in feeding efficiency was noted in salmon fed plant-based protein diets.
[Statement 8]: Some studies found similar feeding efficiency between salmon fed plant-based protein diets and salmon fed fish meal-based diets.
[Statement 9]: The digestibility of feed components was lower in salmon on diets containing plant proteins compared to salmon on fish meal diets.
[Statement 10]: Some studies reported similar levels of digestibility for both plant-based protein diets and fish meal-based diets for salmon.
[Statement 11]: Salmon survival rates were unaffected by either plant-based or fish meal-based protein diets.
[Statement 12]: Salmon appetite was unaffected by either plant-based or fish meal-based protein diets.
[Statement 13]: The morphology of the distal intestine in salmon was altered when the salmon were fed diets with plant-based proteins.
[Statement 14]: The condition of salmon fed plant-based protein diets was found to be increased in one study.
[Statement 15]: The condition of salmon fed plant-based protein diets was found to be reduced in other studies.
[Statement 16]: The use of plant-based oils in salmon feed has also been studied.
[Statement 17]: Studies found similar growth rates in salmon fed diets with fish oil versus salmon fed diets with vegetable oil.
[Statement 18]: Higher growth rates were reported in fish on diets with vegetable oil compared to fish on diets with fish oil.
[Statement 19]: Salmon growth rates in vegetable oil diets were found to be both lower and higher compared to fish oil diets, depending on the family genetics of the salmon.
[Statement 20]: Similar average final body weights were found between groups of salmon fed fish oil diets and groups of salmon fed vegetable oil diets.
[Statement 21]: The fatty acid profile of salmon flesh reflected the oil source in the salmon's diets.
[Statement 22]: The oil source in diets did not affect salmon broodstock fecundity, egg weights, fertility rates, or the weights and development of the salmon broodstock's fry.
[Statement 23]: Salmon on vegetable oil diets had high liver lipid compared to salmon on a fish oil diet.
[Statement 24]: Salmon on vegetable oil diets had low plasma lipoprotein compared to salmon on a fish oil diet.
[Statement 25]: A study found high levels of n-3 highly unsaturated fatty acids in salmon fed fish oil diets compared to salmon fed diets containing rapeseed oil.
[Statement 26]: Salmon on vegetable oil-based diets had lower concentrations of dioxin and polychlorinated biphenyls in the salmon's flesh compared to salmon on diets with fish oil.
[Statement 27]: Fresh, frozen, and smoked salmon flesh from fish fed either fish oil or vegetable oil-based diets had similar levels of gaping, texture, and liquid holding capacity.
[Statement 28]: Pigment concentration was lower in the flesh of salmon fed vegetable oil diets compared to salmon fed fish oil diets.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__What are the documented effects of using plant-based proteins in salmon feed in aquaculture operations in Norway and Scotland?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Several non-chemical alternatives for controlling sea lice on salmon farms have been studied.
[Statement 2]: Using cleaner wrasse as a natural control agent for sea lice has shown mixed results.
[Statement 3]: One study found cleaner wrasse to be as effective as chemical treatments for controlling sea lice.
[Statement 4]: Another study found cleaner wrasse to be ineffective for controlling sea lice.
[Statement 5]: Altering lighting by using low-intensity artificial light or natural lighting has been reported to lower the numbers of lice on salmon.
[Statement 6]: A fallowing system has been recorded to lower lice numbers on Atlantic salmon in cages.
[Statement 7]: A study in Norway found that the number of salmon infected with lice was reduced by 28% when the salmon were fed a diet composed of fish meal and 28% plant-based protein.
[Statement 8]: Adding beta-glucans to the diet of salmon decreased lice infection levels by a further 28%.
[Statement 9]: Probiotics and immunostimulants can increase the survival of salmon exposed to disease-causing bacteria.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__What are the non-chemical alternatives for controlling sea lice on salmon farms?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: A study in Scotland recorded lower lice numbers on Atlantic salmon in cages using a fallowing system.
[Statement 2]: A study in Australia found no difference in mortality from Amoebic Gill Disease in cages where a fallowing system had been used.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__How does the effectiveness of fallowing salmon farm cages for disease control vary between studies in Scotland and Australia?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Fish fed a fishmeal diet weighed more than fish fed diets with alternative animal proteins.
[Statement 2]: There were no differences in weight between Atlantic salmon that were fed diets containing the yeast Yarrowia lipolytica compared to a control diet containing fishmeal.
[Statement 3]: Salmon that were fed diets containing fish meal only had similar final weight gain to salmon that were fed a krill meal substitute.
[Statement 4]: When the krill were de-shelled, salmon growth rates were closer to the growth rates of salmon fed fish meal, compared to leaving the krill whole.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__How do krill, yeast, and animal protein alternatives to fishmeal compare in their effect on Atlantic salmon growth?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Several studies in Norway have explored alternative feed components for Atlantic salmon.

[Statement 5]: Some Norwegian studies showed Atlantic salmon fed plant-based diets had reduced final body weights.
[Statement 6]: Other Norwegian studies found no difference in final body weights of Atlantic salmon fed plant-based diets.
[Statement 7]: Feeding efficiency was varied in Norwegian studies of Atlantic salmon on plant-based diets.
[Statement 8]: Some Norwegian studies showed a decrease in feeding efficiency for Atlantic salmon fed plant-based diets.
[Statement 9]: One Norwegian study showed an increase in feeding efficiency for Atlantic salmon fed a plant-based diet.
[Statement 10]: Two studies in Norway found that the morphology of the distal intestine was altered in salmon fed plant-based protein diets.
[Statement 11]: One experiment in Norway found no difference in weight for salmon fed diets with Yarrowia lipolytica compared to salmon fed fishmeal.

[Statement 13]: One of the three Norwegian studies on genetically modified soybeans also found no differences in the salmon's histology.

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Salmon housed in larger cages exhibited lower rates of amoebic gill disease when compared to salmon in smaller cages.
[Statement 2]: A replicated and controlled study conducted in Norway revealed that salmon exposed to low-intensity artificial light or natural lighting had fewer lice.
[Statement 3]: The number of lice on salmon increased in correlation with the intensity of the artificial light.

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: A study in Scotland reported lower lice numbers on Atlantic salmon in cages that used a fallowing system.
[Statement 2]: A study in Australia found no difference in mortality from Amoebic Gill Disease in cages where a fallowing system was used.
[Statement 3]: Two studies in Australia presented mixed results for reducing amoebic gill disease using freshwater bathing.
[Statement 4]: One study found a reduction in the number of amoebae on salmon gills that lasted for up to 10 days after bathing.
[Statement 5]: A replicated, controlled study found similar levels of amoebae in the gills of both treated and untreated salmon.

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: A replicated, controlled experiment in Norway found no differences in weight between Atlantic salmon that were fed diets containing the yeast Yarrowia lipolytica compared to a control diet containing fishmeal.
[Statement 2]: A controlled, replicated study in Australia found no difference in weight gain of Atlantic salmon with and without dietary supplementation of phytase and phosphate.
[Statement 3]: A controlled, replicated study in Norway found no difference in weight gain of salmon that were fed diets with or without taurine supplementation.
[Statement 4]: One controlled, randomised, replicated study from Scotland showed that fish fed a fishmeal diet weighed more than fish fed diets with alternative proteins.
[Statement 5]: A controlled, replicated study in Australia found that fish fed diets supplemented with phytase had greater final weights than fish given no supplement.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__Which dietary alternatives or supplements to traditional fish meal have been shown to have no negative impact on Atlantic salmon growth or weight?
_gemini-2-5-pro__What is the evidence that integrated aquaculture systems or constructing artificial reefs can mitigate the environmental impacts of salmon farms?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: A study in Canada found that blue mussels absorbed waste from a salmon farm.
[Statement 2]: A replicated, controlled study in the USA reported greater growth of scallops grown next to fish farms.
[Statement 3]: A replicated, controlled study in Scotland reported enhanced algal growth when placed adjacent to fish farms.
[Statement 4]: One study in Spain found no evidence that oysters and mussels were feeding on fish farm waste.
[Statement 5]: No studies were found that evaluated the effects on subtidal benthic invertebrate populations of using species from more than one level of a food web in aquaculture systems.
[Statement 6]: One controlled study in the Red Sea found no difference in sediment carbon at artificial reef sites adjacent to or away from fish farms.
[Statement 7]: A controlled study in the Red Sea reports that artificial reefs at sites both adjacent to and away from fish farms were colonized with various species with the potential to remove organic compounds from fish farm effluents.
[Statement 8]: One controlled study in the Mediterranean Sea found that an artificial reef located under aquaculture cages had a similar invertebrate community composition to artificial reefs located at sites without aquaculture cages.
[Statement 9]: One controlled study in the Gulf of Aqaba found that an artificial reef located at an aquaculture site had similar invertebrate biomass growing on it compared to an artificial reef located at a site without aquaculture cages.
[Statement 10]: No studies were found that evaluated the effects of locating artificial reefs near aquaculture systems to act as biofilters on subtidal benthic invertebrate populations.

[Statement 1]: A study in Norway indicated that aerobic training could enhance the survival rates of salmon suffering from infectious pancreatic necrosis.
[Statement 2]: Interval training is more effective than continuous training for enhancing the survival rates of salmon suffering from infectious pancreatic necrosis.
[Statement 3]: A study in Australia revealed that salmon housed in larger cages exhibited reduced levels of amoebic gill disease when compared to salmon in smaller cages.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__How do physical interventions like aerobic training and altering cage size affect the health and survival of farmed Atlantic salmon?
_gemini-2-5-pro__What are the observed effects on salmon growth and flesh quality when replacing fish oil with plant-based or other animal-based oils in their diet?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Three replicated studies in Norway found similar growth rates in salmon when replacing fish oil with plant-based oils in their diets.
[Statement 2]: One study reported higher growth rates in salmon fed vegetable oil compared to fish oil.
[Statement 3]: Another study found that salmon growth rates depended on the salmon's family genetics when fish oil was replaced.
[Statement 4]: Two replicated studies in Norway found similar average final body weights between salmon fed fish oil and salmon fed vegetable oil diets.
[Statement 5]: Three studies in Norway and Scotland noted that the fatty acid profile of the salmon flesh reflected the dietary oil source.
[Statement 6]: A replicated, controlled study in Scotland revealed that salmon on vegetable oil-based diets had lower levels of dioxin and polychlorinated biphenyls in their flesh.
[Statement 7]: A Norwegian study indicated that flesh quality attributes like gaping, texture, and liquid holding capacity were similar between salmon fed vegetable oil and salmon fed fish oil diets.
[Statement 8]: The same Norwegian study indicated that pigment concentration was lower in the flesh of the vegetable oil-fed salmon group.
[Statement 9]: One controlled, replicated study in Canada found no difference in oxygen consumption or swimming speed of Atlantic salmon fed diets with anchovy oil versus alternative lipid sources.

[Statement 1]: Three controlled, replicated studies in Norway found no difference in the growth rate of Atlantic salmon fed diets containing either genetically modified (GM) or non-GM soybeans.
[Statement 2]: One randomised, replicated, controlled study in Norway also found no differences in the histology of fish fed diets containing either GM or non-GM soybeans.
[Statement 3]: One controlled, replicated study in Australia found no difference in weight gain of Atlantic salmon with and without dietary supplementation of phytase and phosphate.
[Statement 4]: Another controlled, replicated study in Australia found that fish fed diets supplemented with phytase had greater final weights than fish given no supplement.
[Statement 5]: A controlled, replicated study in Norway found no difference in weight gain of salmon that were fed diets with or without taurine supplementation.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__What is the evidence regarding the effect of using genetically modified ingredients or dietary supplements on the growth of Atlantic salmon?

parts.text:

[Statement 2]: Two controlled studies in Norway reported higher survival rates for salmon vaccinated against infectious salmon anaemia.
